column2: He isn't fit to hear what's said here.	He isn't fit to hear what's said here.

column2: He glared at me, as if he didn't know who I was, when I went downstairs. His heart was going like a hammer.	He glared at me, as if he didn't know who I was, when I went downstairs. His heart was going like a hammer.

I wish he had never been to school, Mrs Verloc began again brusquely. "He's always taking away those newspapers from the window to read.
column3: I wish he had never been to school, Mrs Verloc began again brusquely. "He's always taking away those newspapers from the window to read.

column2: He gets a red face poring over them.
column3: He gets a red face poring over them.

column2: We don't get rid of a dozen numbers in a month.
column3: We don't get rid of a dozen numbers in a month.

column2: And Mr Ossipon brings every week a pile of these F. P. tracts to sell at a halfpenny each.
column3: And Mr Ossipon brings every week a pile of these f p tracts to sell at a halfpenny each.

column2: I wouldn't give a halfpenny for the whole lot.
column3: I wouldn't give a halfpenny for the whole lot.

column2: It's silly reading--that's what it is.
column3: It's silly reading-that's what it is.

column2: There's no sale for it.
The other day Stevie got hold of one, and there was a story in it of a German soldier officer tearing half-off the ear of a recruit, and nothing was done to him for it.
column3: The other day Stevie got hold of one, and there was a story in it of a German soldier officer tearing half off the ear of a recruit, and nothing was done to him for it.

column2: The brute!
I couldn't do anything with Stevie that afternoon.
column3: I couldn't do anything with Stevie that afternoon.

column2: The story was enough, too, to make one's blood boil.
column3: The story was enough, too, to make one's blood boil.

column2: But what's the use of printing things like that?
column3: But what's the use of printing things like that?

column2: We aren't German slaves here, thank God.
